ygData.subject: Re: [Re: Name Debate]
ygData.msgSnippet: Joseph- Just re-read the second paragraph of Christina s post. Do you see why I suggested it? I originally laughed out loud at my thought of calling the guild
ygData.messageBody:
Joseph-

Just re-read the second paragraph of Christina's post. Do you see why I
suggested it? I originally laughed out loud at my thought of calling the guild
Mystic Gaydar, but then Mystic Alliance seemed pretty good. Not that every
GLBT man and woman feel called to associate with each other, but obviously a
bunch of us here do... that's mystical, spiritual, mysterious, magical... and
everything wrapped up together. No religious affiliation is taken from the
name either. Although angels and archangels, etc. sound nice, most people did
not want to inject Judeo-Christian ideas into Norrathian culture.

It's almost certain that no one name will be the ultimate to everyone
involved. Arriving at a consensus fairly soon would be great as I am excited
and wanting to let everyone I know about it. Having the name to relay with the
rest of the information is important to start building a guild identity and
presence.

Thanks for your ideas-

Christine

Joseph Normandin <josephn@...> wrote:
From: Joseph Normandin <josephn@...>

I just cant shut up

the name is cool but what would be "mystic"? It has to refer to
somehting. Do we seek mytery? or we mystic? the name has to ahhve some
meaning yes?

-joe

On 29 Jul 1999, Christine Greenwald wrote:

> From: Christine Greenwald <ChrisRAV4@...>
>
> I like the story as well, and I agree with Christina that we don't need to
be
> outcasts. As far as names for the women in the history, there's a couple I
> have in mind, but need to look up tonight before posting.
>
> In reading your message, Christina, another name came to mind <as she
> cautiously tosses it into the fray>: Mystic Alliance
>
> I think the GLBT-related names have pretty much been dropped in discussion
by
> most people. This name is role-play appropriate, it is somewhat mysterious
and
> the alliance part is what we are about. There is nothing good/evil impliant
in
> the name, nor any specific class or race.
>
> Although the GLBT link may not be apparent in any name chosen, it is easy
> enough to add symbolism to any graphics/logo associated with a guild site.
> Granted, it wouldn't be visually attached to our names in the game, but if
> people want to know, they'll ask or look for a website for information.
>
> As far as publicity for the guild once things are a bit settled, PlanetOut
> might be a great online zine to contact. Their turnaround time for getting
> information out is much quicker than the print media. I think they may also
> have links to GLBT websites, which would be great when we have one for the
> guild. I can't recall if there is a gay-related news service bureau. Some
> individuals were trying to create one a while ago. The BBC is very queer
> friendly and could be interested in a story, especially if we wish to reach
> our brothers and sisters in the EU. Wired may also be a good place to reach
> GLBT gamers and they have their email newsletters as well.
>
> I enjoyed chatting with you all in the guild formation last night. This is
the
> start of something really great.
>
> Christine
> Ananda, cleric of Brell Serilis on Brell
> Mirri, druid of Tunare on Brell
>
>
> Date: Thu, 29 Jul 99 12:52PM MST
> From: Christina Norman <tina@...>
> To: EQ_rainbow@onelist.com
> Subject:
> Re: [EQ_rainbow] Guild Operational Details and Backstory
> More Details
>
>
> From: Christina Norman <tina@...>
>
>
> I'm fine with this story. I don't see the need for us to be outcasts
> though. I personally prefer to assume that Norathian culture is generally
> accepting of diverse sexual orientation, and that players who express
> otherwise are members of some strange minority.
>
> One thing I would like to see in terms of roleplay is that GLBT and
> positive people share a kind of bond that is manifests itself as a
> tangible spiritual connection. Something along the lines of us all coming
> together because we had this connection, and could sense it in eachother.
> Kind of a mystic gaydar 8) I like it because this implies a reason for us
> to exist in an organization beyond combating homophobia (which implies
> homophobia is a force requiring an organization to combat).
>
> - Christina
>
> On Thu, 29 Jul 1999, David Lari wrote:
> > From: David Lari <kerik@...>
> > My ideas for our charter and lower down the 'back story' thing I
promised
>
> > yesterday.
>
>
